heisig_chinese_memo: A month is longer than a day. The extended strokes for the right and left sides extend further.
heisig_constituent: month, moon, month, flesh, part of the body
heisig_story: This character is actually a picture of the moon, with the two horizontal lines representing the left eye and mouth of the mythical "man in the moon." (Actually, the Japanese see a hare in the moon, but it is a little farfetched to find one in the kanji.) And one month, of course, is one cycle of the moon.
koohiiStory1: A month is longer than a day.
koohiiStory2: Am I the only one who sees this as someone sticking their ass in the air "mooning" someone (two cheeks of the butt and the legs coming off of it)? The Moon meaning connects well to the meaning of month, considering that months were traditionally measured by the phases of the moon. Also, the mooning "ass" part of it connects well to HesigÂ´s seemingly unconnected "flesh" or "part of the body" meaning (when used in primitive form).

humanum_full_description_en:
A gold inscription like the shape of a half moon. The original meaning is the moon. Based on the cycle of profit and loss in the month, the word â€œmonthâ€ also indicates the month of the year in the calendar.

The oracle bone inscriptions mean the moon, as in "Compilation" 11483: "On the eve of the moon, there is an eclipse of the moon." "There is an eclipse of the moon" is a lunar eclipse. Jia Jinwen is also used as a unit word to record the calendar, indicating the month. For example, "Compilation" 5658 is: "Ding (Zhen): This November the emperor will not make rain." Zhu Ding: "Jun (Wei) the first year of the king in June."

" Moon " and " Xi " were originally expressed in the same glyph, there is no difference in the moon shape. Later, due to the division of labor in different bodies, one point in the moon shape was used to represent " moon ", and no point in the moon shape to represent " evening ", which split into two different shapes of characters. (Qiu Xigui) See " Xi ".
humanum_short_description_en: Inscriptions like a half-moon. The original meaning is the moon. Based on the cycle of profit and loss in the month, the word â€œmonthâ€ also indicates the month of the year in the calendar.

Also, the mooning "ass" part of it connects well to HesigÂ´s seemingly unconnected "flesh" or "part of the body" meaning (when used in primitive form).

A gold inscription like the shape of a half moon. The original meaning is the moon. Based on the cycle of profit and loss in the month, the word â€œmonthâ€ also indicates the month of the year in the calendar. The oracle bone inscriptions mean the moon, as in "Compilation" 11483: "On the eve of the moon, there is an eclipse of the moon." "There is an eclipse of the moon" is a lunar eclipse. Jia Jinwen is also used as a unit word to record the calendar, indicating the month. For example, "Compilation" 5658 is: "Ding (Zhen): This November the emperor will not make rain." Zhu Ding: "Jun (Wei) the first year of the king in June." " Moon" and " Xi" were originally expressed in the same glyph, there is no difference in the moon shape. Later, due to the division of labor in different bodies, one point in the moon shape was used to represent " moon", and no point in the moon shape to represent " evening", which split into two different shapes of characters. (Qiu Xigui) See " Xi".
